class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    The SWELLS survey \u2013 I. A large spectroscopically selected sample of edge-on late-type lens galaxies\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Tommaso Treu\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-c1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"c1\" $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f417%2f3%2f1601%2f1083532\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612843 id=\"19612843\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The relative contribution of baryons and dark matter to the inner regions of spiral galaxies provides critical clues to their formation and evolution, but it is generally difficult to determine. For spiral galaxies that are strong gravitational lenses, however, the combination of lensing and kinematic observations can be used to break the disc\u2013halo degeneracy. In turn, such data constrain fundamental parameters such as (i) the mass density profile slope and axial ratio of the dark matter halo, and by comparison with dark matter-only numerical simulations the modifications imposed by baryons; (ii) the mass in stars and therefore the overall star formation efficiency, and the amount of feedback; (iii) by comparison with stellar population synthesis models, the normalization of the stellar initial mass function. In this first paper of a series, we present a sample of 16 secure, one probable and six possible strong lensing spiral galaxies, for which multiband high-resolution images and rotation curves were obtained using the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and Keck II telescope as part of the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS). The sample includes eight newly discovered secure systems. We characterize the sample of deflector galaxies in terms of their morphologies, structural parameters and stellar masses. We find that the SWELLS sample of secure lenses spans a broad range of morphologies (from lenticular to late-type spiral), spectral types (quantified by H\u03b1 emission) and bulge to total stellar mass ratio (0.22\u20130.85), while being limited to <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> &gt; 10<sup>10.5</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The SWELLS sample is thus well suited for exploring the relationship between dark and luminous matter in a broad range of galaxies. We find that the deflector galaxies obey the same size\u2013mass relation as that of a comparison sample of elongated non-lens galaxies selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. We conclude that the SWELLS sample is consistent with being representative of the overall population of high-mass high-inclination discy galaxies.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: fundamental parameters&quot;\">galaxies: fundamental parameters</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: haloes&quot;\">galaxies: haloes</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: spiral&quot;\">galaxies: spiral</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: structure&quot;\">galaxies: structure</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612845 id=\"19612845\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of extended flat rotation curves in the outer parts of disc galaxies three decades ago (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bosma 1978</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rubin, Thonnard &amp; Ford 1978</a>) was decisive in ushering the paradigm shift that led to the now standard cosmological model dominated by cold dark matter (CDM) and dark energy. On cosmological (i.e. linear) scales there is excellent agreement between the predictions of the standard \u039bCDM model and observations of the cosmic microwave background (CMB), Type Ia supernovae, weak lensing and galaxy clustering (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spergel et al. 2007</a>). On galactic and subgalactic (i.e. non-linear) scales, however, there are a number of apparent discrepancies between the predictions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro, Frenk &amp; White 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>) and observations (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Klypin et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Moore et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">de Blok, McGaugh &amp; Rubin 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swaters et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newton et al. 2011</a>) of the structure and mass function of dark matter haloes. Whether these problems reflect an incomplete understanding of galaxy formation, or signal an unresolvable problem for the standard paradigm, remains to be determined. Measuring the density profiles of dark matter haloes on galaxy scales is thus a crucial test for the standard paradigm of galaxy formation, offering great potential for discovery.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In most luminous galaxies the baryons (i.e. stars and cold gas) always make a non-negligible contribution to the gravitational potential, and due to the so-called <em>disc\u2013halo degeneracy</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van Albada &amp; Sancisi 1986</a>) the distribution of baryons and dark matter in galaxies is poorly constrained, even when high spatial resolution rotation curves are available (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van den Bosch &amp; Swaters 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2005</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A potentially powerful method for breaking the disc\u2013halo degeneracy is to combine galaxy kinematics with strong gravitational lensing (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maller et al. 2000</a>). This method makes use of the fact that kinematics measures mass enclosed within a sphere, while strong lensing measures projected mass (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu 2010</a>, and references therein). The power of strong gravitational lensing and dynamics to break the disc\u2013halo degeneracy has, to date, not been fully realized, due to the scarcity of known spiral galaxy gravitational lenses. Up until a few years ago, only a handful of spiral galaxy lenses with suitable inclinations to enable rotation curve measurements were known: Q2237+0305 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Huchra et al. 1985</a>); B1600+434 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jaunsen &amp; Hjorth 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koopmans, de Bruyn &amp; Jackson 1998</a>); PMN J2004\u22121349 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Winn, Hall &amp; Schechter 2003</a>) and CXOCY J220132.8\u2212320144 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Castander et al. 2006</a>). However, most of these systems are doubly imaged quasi-stellar objects (QSOs), which provide minimal constraints on the projected mass distribution. Q2237+0305 is a quadruply imaged QSO, which gives more robust constraints, but since the Einstein radius is five times smaller than the half-light size of the galaxy, the lensing is mostly sensitive to the bulge mass (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Trott et al. 2010</a>). Recently, extensive searches based on large parent surveys have started to find gravitational lens candidates where the deflector is a spiral galaxy. Examples of imaging-based searches for spiral lens galaxies include those by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sygnet et al. (2010)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Marshall et al. (2009)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">More et al. (2011)</a>, while spectroscopy-based searches include those by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">F\u00e9ron et al. (2009)</a> and the Sloan Lens ACS (SLACS) Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al.</a> 2009). One of the main challenges of identifying and studying strong lens systems where the deflector is a spiral galaxy is the presence of dust. Modelling and correcting for dust obscuration is essential to model the gravitational potential of the deflector; this can be done by exploiting the conservation of surface brightness of the background source in gravitational lensing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since its beginning in <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) cycle 13, SLACS has discovered 85 strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses (and an additional 13 high probability candidates). Because of the strong dependency of the lensing cross-section on central surface mass density, \u223c90 per cent of the lenses discovered by SLACS have been massive early-type galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>). However, thanks to its large overall size, SLACS was able to discover a considerable number of previously unknown gravitational lens systems with a deflector of spiral morphology. 10 SLACS lenses have visible spiral morphology (classification S or S0/Sa). Of these 10, eight have disc inclinations high enough (<em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6) for measuring reliable rotation curves. This subset alone already more than doubles the sample of previously known systems. In addition, source and deflector redshifts are known by construction for the SLACS systems, and the deflector galaxy is generally bright and at a relatively low redshift, making it a very practical sample for detailed follow-up. The main limitations of the SLACS-spiral sample are that it is limited to bulge-dominated spirals, since they are the most common in strong lensing selected samples, and that spatially resolved kinematics is not available from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) fibre-based spectroscopy, but requires follow-up (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnabe et al. 2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The goal of the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS; WFC = Wide Field Camera) project is to identify, follow-up and analyse in a systematic fashion a large and homogeneous sample of spiral lens galaxies. We aim to combine strong gravitational lensing with stellar kinematics to break the \u2018disc\u2013halo\u2019 degeneracy and address two fundamental issues. First, measurements of dark matter halo density profiles and halo shapes will be compared to predictions of galaxy formation models in the concordance \u039bCDM cosmology. Secondly, measurements of stellar mass-to-light ratios will be compared to those predicted from stellar population models, thus placing constraints on the stellar initial mass function (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spiniello et al. 2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The sample consists of high-inclination spiral lens galaxies, drawn from both the SLACS Survey and a new dedicated SDSS/<em>HST</em> search. For each object in its target list, the SWELLS survey is measuring high-quality rotation and velocity dispersion profiles using long-slit spectroscopy at the Keck telescopes. In addition, high-resolution images in multiple bands, including the infrared with Keck, are being obtained to model and correct dust obscuration, identify and model multiple images of the background source and infer stellar masses of bulge and disc from stellar population synthesis models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this first paper of the series we present an overview of the survey and the lens sample, and discuss the lensing galaxies as spiral galaxies to identify potential selection effects that must be taken into account when interpreting our results. Papers of this series will present detailed analyses of the individual systems illustrating the methodology and challenges of a joint lensing and dynamical study of spiral galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011b</a>, hereafter Paper II) and a library of gravitational lens models (Brewer et al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. Our strategy and sample selection algorithm is described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 2</a>. The data are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 4</a> we present lensing classification, morphological and structural properties and stellar masses for each system. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 5</a> we discuss the lensing galaxies as spiral galaxies, by comparing them to a control sample drawn from the SDSS. We discuss our findings and the lessons learned with an eye to future searches for strong lensing spirals in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 6</a>. A brief summary is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7\"></span><a href=\"#ss7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 7</a>. Throughout this paper, and the rest of the SWELLS series, magnitudes are given in the AB system (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oke 1974</a>) and we adopt standard \u2018concordance\u2019 cosmological parameters, i.e. <em>h</em> = 0.7, \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-mu1.gif?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=pVZDa628O~75p5AOf3YBsxvTy7mUAWL439XvQsIDJdgWPU~BMq12QqoXwSe6gJTydKgQNCGtFASu10oYs5ijAGPhl~EIPV5af-FfjbzOARAaD~IwtTbFobVT8CyG0C7pBgHb~NnKxmy41EFjah40Wej9lKeg7kI~OzIXQvawlXC5-p1VdbLuFuflK827S9i-XZystvNTSfN7NrOYyWnYjCr3C0aswHIxIjXmU19QVwcSJgDKbYvzMYt-IawLUC1WY945Df1YFTKy9p2R1giJYjOG319AfxUrXnH786M9rlQ96rp4-vL5Fb72X5mwjWkYK3DFORSI1hjXBgplfvkNmg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>, where the symbols indicate the Hubble constant in units of 100 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> and the matter and dark energy density of the Universe in units of the critical density (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Komatsu et al. 2009</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612860 id=\"19612860\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 SAMPLE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SWELLS sample is composed of two subsamples. The first is a subset of the spiral lens galaxies identified by the SLACS Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>), suitable for kinematic follow-up due to their high inclination, as determined by the observed axial ratio. The second subsample consists of new spiral lens galaxies, identified from the SDSS data base and confirmed with <em>HST</em> imaging in the following manner. The strategy is similar to that adopted for the original SLACS sample, optimized to identify spiral lens galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we looked for SDSS spectra that contain two sets of lines at two different redshifts, indicating a foreground and background object in the same 3-arcsec-diameter solid angle covered by the fibre as detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Appendix A</a>. Out of almost a million spectra, our spectroscopic search algorithm found more than 200 new high-probability lens candidates. Secondly, SDSS images of the lens candidates were visually inspected by two of us (TT and AAD) to identify those spiral galaxies sufficiently inclined for rotation curve measurements, and to reject obvious failures or contaminants. Thirdly, we estimated the strong lensing probability according to the following procedure. Based on our previous experience (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2008</a>), the lens confirmation rate is a well known and monotonically increasing function of Einstein radius (effectively, proportional to the fraction of the solid angle of the fibre that is contained within the critical lines, plus seeing and other observational effects). The Einstein radius was estimated from the velocity dispersion of the lens and the usual ratio of angular diameter distances, assuming that the stellar velocity dispersion equals the normalization of the best-fitting singular isothermal ellipsoid (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2008</a>). Since velocity dispersions are not always available or reliable, especially for the more disc-dominated systems with emission lines, we used total luminosity as a proxy for stellar velocity dispersion, after calibrating the correlation on the rest of the sample. We expect this to be a conservative estimate, since edge-on systems are more effective lenses due to their higher projected mass density (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maller, Flores &amp; Primack 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Keeton &amp; Kochanek 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Blain, Moller &amp; Maller 1999</a>). Fourthly, to optimize use of telescope time, we excluded all targets with estimated lensing probability below 30 per cent. This left a total sample of 43 candidates, which we used to select targets for high-resolution imaging follow-up based on observability. If more than one candidate was observable at a given time, we gave priority to those with the highest estimated lensing probability. Follow-up observations and lens confirmation rates are discussed in the next sections.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A total of 27 candidates were observed with high-resolution imaging. A summary of the properties of these SWELLS lenses and candidates is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"19612864\" scrollto-destination=\"19612864\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the lens grade (A \u2013 secure, B \u2013 probable, C \u2013 possible, X \u2013 not a lens) according to the definition of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2006)</a>; column 7 the velocity dispersion within the spectroscopic fibre as measured by SDSS; column 8 the H\u03b1 flux as measured by SDSS spectroscopy based on the subtracted model spectrum; column 9 the axial ratio as measured by SDSS and column 10 the reference for the discovery of the lens (1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, 2 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2008</a>, 3 \u2013 this paper).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the lens grade (A \u2013 secure, B \u2013 probable, C \u2013 possible, X \u2013 not a lens) according to the definition of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2006)</a>; column 7 the velocity dispersion within the spectroscopic fibre as measured by SDSS; column 8 the H\u03b1 flux as measured by SDSS spectroscopy based on the subtracted model spectrum; column 9 the axial ratio as measured by SDSS and column 10 the reference for the discovery of the lens (1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, 2 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2008</a>, 3 \u2013 this paper).</p></div> </div><div \u00b1 13\u00a0</td><td>21.7 \u00b1 3.9\u00a0</td><td>0.30\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2210\u22120934\u00a0</td><td>332.52393\u00a0</td><td>\u22129.57112\u00a0</td><td>0.083\u00a0</td><td>1.158\u00a0</td><td>C\u00a0</td><td>133 \u00b1 10\u00a0</td><td>\u22c5\u22c5\u22c5\u00a0</td><td>0.25\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/19612864\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612865 id=\"19612865\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612866 id=\"19612866\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1 <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the supplementary cycle 16s we were awarded 91 orbits (of which 74 were executed) of <em>HST</em> time to discover new spiral galaxy lenses and to complete three-band optical imaging of the known SLACS spiral lenses (GO-11978; PI: Treu). As a compromise between maximum wavelength coverage \u2013 needed to model and correct dust obscuration, identify strongly lensed features and model stellar populations \u2013 and efficiency, we chose to image each lens through the <em>F450W</em>, <em>F606W</em> and <em>F814W</em> filters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of GO-11978, 20 new candidates (selected as described in the previous section) were scheduled to be observed. Of those, 15 were observed with Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2) in three bands: <em>F450W</em> (two orbits), <em>F606W</em> (one orbit) and <em>F814W</em> (one orbit), and one was observed in <em>F450W</em> and <em>F606W</em> (two and one orbit, respectively). Because of scheduling constraints the <em>F814W</em> exposure and remaining four targets were not observed.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a> In addition, five SLACS-selected spiral lenses (J0841+3824, J1029+0420, J1032+5322, J1103+5322 and J2141-0001) were imaged in <em>F450W</em> (two orbits each) and/or <em>F606W</em> (one orbit) to complete three-band imaging for the sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All targets were placed in the centre of the WFPC2-WF3 chip, which has a pixel scale of 0.1 arcsec. The observations in each filter consisted of four exposures dithered by fractional pixel amounts to remove defects, identify cosmic ray hits and to recover resolution lost to undersampling. The raw images were reduced and combined using a custom built pipeline based on the <span class=\"small-caps\">drizzle</span> package, resulting in final images with a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additional <em>HST</em> imaging is available for the SLACS subsample as listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>. Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)/WFCP2 and Near Infrared Camera and Multi-Object Spectrometer (NICMOS) observations are presented in the papers by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. Infrared images obtained with WFC3 through filter <em>F160W</em> as part of GO-11202 (PI: Koopmans) are presented here for the first time. As with the other instruments, a standard four-point dither strategy was adopted, in this case to remove defects and recover some of the information lost to the undersampling of the point spread function (PSF) by the 0.13 arcsec pixels. The data were reduced via a custom pipeline based on the <span class=\"small-caps\">drizzle</span> package, using the most up to date calibration files.</p>                        <a id=\"19612871\" scrollto-destination=\"19612871\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric, structural and stellar mass parameters of the SWELLS systems. For each lens the first line lists the bulge parameters (when detected), while the second line lists the disc parameters. Typical uncertainties are 0.05 mag on magnitudes, 10 per cent on effective radii and axial ratios (<em>q</em>=<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>), dominated by systematics (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>, and references therein). Apparent magnitudes are not corrected for galactic extinction. Effective radii are given along the intermediate axis; major-axis effective radii can be obtained by dividing by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-mu4.gif?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=IKXwRBBMk3cEBwuRHGvwKsLRRNj9lbwIZA2ippAwHO4x7XDKrPgFip74jltwFMXb4UEXw6cvI-sZ4SChVzXWuVD1viL12cx0K8yfx4ghyYIgr7-MyvkQw0sZ-o9mgUiHnchRsml-8opzMJLXiYK9WKCppK6STiDTTN02ZRgJtJeRVluMTJ1zLlGiMlXIPx9fyS-pOZiOiFo8rmnly2J1cT1bQbH6lvRhyinNB49ip0oy5wJfBGEvKwu7Dd7yAig2i6xydK54nS~Iu4DQrZ~l0FNllv7QwRJEYoqWPZrNx9iJW09rTTXdC5SQrW5IB3949~7peVjnKjcR9zFDxmLVGw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-mu4.gif\" />\u2060</span>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ID\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em><sub>WFPC2</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em><sub>ACS</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>V</em><sub>WFPC2</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>I</em><sub>WFPC2</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>I</em><sub>ACS</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>NIC2</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>WFC3</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em>\u2032<sub>AO</sub>\u00a0</td><td><em>R</em><sub>e</sub>/kpc\u00a0</td><td><em>q</em>\u00a0</td><td>log table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric, structural and stellar mass parameters of the SWELLS systems. For each lens the first line lists the bulge parameters (when detected), while the second line lists the disc parameters. Typical uncertainties are 0.05 mag on magnitudes, 10 per cent on effective radii and axial ratios (<em>q</em>=<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>), dominated by systematics (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>, and references therein). Apparent magnitudes are not corrected for galactic extinction. Effective radii are given along the intermediate axis; major-axis effective radii can be obtained by dividing by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-mu4.gif?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=IKXwRBBMk3cEBwuRHGvwKsLRRNj9lbwIZA2ippAwHO4x7XDKrPgFip74jltwFMXb4UEXw6cvI-sZ4SChVzXWuVD1viL12cx0K8yfx4ghyYIgr7-MyvkQw0sZ-o9mgUiHnchRsml-8opzMJLXiYK9WKCppK6STiDTTN02ZRgJtJeRVluMTJ1zLlGiMlXIPx9fyS-pOZiOiFo8rmnly2J1cT1bQbH6lvRhyinNB49ip0oy5wJfBGEvKwu7Dd7yAig2i6xydK54nS~Iu4DQrZ~l0FNllv7QwRJEYoqWPZrNx9iJW09rTTXdC5SQrW5IB3949~7peVjnKjcR9zFDxmLVGw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td><td>10.08 \u00b1 0.13\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/19612871\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612874 id=\"19612874\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2 Keck adaptive optics imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">High-resolution infrared imaging is extremely valuable for dust correction, multiple image identification and stellar mass estimation. For these purposes, <em>K</em>\u2032-band (2.15 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-mu2.gif?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=GCx~uHRiPR23z1pByNdIh1kfVeKHdpQsanSORt8bwRN2yZQq2-zMEmFys0M4r3rdakmWRhCt83v5gMvxpP78b5YujrslBp7FrKMwR86PfTCOJESB2n-s2Jr6Vavn7QoldcocclkMGiK5xHrQ7C7IrMxoER9p9GtCJglLBuZVWnQb4zwlpxaTHRi-K2Y19QNGhmQMYk5RZ-v8j9JxoJLFR3txdtILUx5MESPGPjX6XQqfjoFkIy7yBmnIRFC-b~spJFLUkMenYss33ZPpRNb2BfAFVHKdolK1EYMOoQkELm6RixXPTOhZI1NKJq9hJnRVQeKy55rSE6dcRg6Issx7Kw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-mu2.gif\" /></span>m) imaging was obtained for a subset of candidates/lenses for which a suitable bright nearby star is available for tip-tilt correction using the LGSAO system on the Keck II 10-m telescope. Higher priority was given to those systems for which <em>HST</em> infrared imaging is not available, although the combination of <em>HST</em>-<em>F160W</em> and ground-based <em>K</em>\u2032-band imaging is especially powerful. The sensitivity of Keck AO at longer wavelengths complements very nicely the <em>HST</em> PSF stability and sensitivity to low surface brightness features, helping in particular with dust correction and stellar mass estimates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All observations were performed with the Near-Infrared Camera 2 (NIRC2) camera in wide field mode, yielding a pixel scale of 0.04 arcsec, typical resolution of 0.10 arcsec full width at half-maximum (FWHM) and Strehl ratio of 0.15\u20130.20. The observations took place on the following dates, during times of clear sky and good seeing conditions suitable for AO correction: 2009 November 11 (PI: Koo); 2009 May 7/8, 2009 August 12, 2010 January 4 (PI: Treu). Typical exposure times ranged between 30 and 60 min, depending on conditions and faintness of the target. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> lists the targets that were observed with AO. More details on the observations of individual systems will be given in future papers along with the analysis of the systems themselves. Although in general the lensed features are rather blue and more easily identified in <em>HST</em> images, we note that two of the grade A SWELLS lenses were observed only with Keck-AO, and confirmed from the ground.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All NIRC2 data were reduced with a custom <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>-based reduction package described by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2011)</a>. A sky frame and a sky flat were created from the individual science exposures after masking out all objects. Frames were then flat-fielded and sky-subtracted. The images were de-warped to correct for known camera distortion. The frames were aligned by centroiding on objects in the field; each frame was then drizzled to a common output frame, and these output frames were median-combined to produce the final image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An empirical model for the PSF was derived from observations of stars. In some cases a star was close enough to the lens galaxy to fall in the NIRC2 field of view and be used as a model PSF. In other cases a PSF star pair was used; this separate observation involves observing a star cluster, and using as a PSF model a star that is at the same distance from its tip-tilt correction star as the lens galaxy was from its tip-tilt star. The star pair observations were made immediately following the lens observations.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612879 id=\"19612879\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 SAMPLE PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the overall properties of the sample. First, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a> we present our classification of the lensing morphology, providing notes on each of the systems based on visual inspection of multicolour images and deflector-subtracted images. These images are presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We note that subtracting the light of the deflector galaxy is much more challenging for the spiral galaxies of the SWELLS sample, compared e.g. to the smoother early-type galaxies that compose the SLACS sample. For this reason the deflector subtracted images shown in this paper are used only for the classification of lensing morphology. In future papers, we will discuss alternative strategies to disentangle light from the source and the deflector for the purpose of lens modelling.</p>                        <a id=\"19612881\" scrollto-destination=\"19612881\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=YquOg9UMTJqeA23PBABDf~8Kp~rZVob1Ie0abPWs3Xb~gLetHpgpKqA6BcNRi5N8rxIVqZxyRtqb1gw~9dcvxDI5R86gzS3Xud6fmwK5HuX55EmeqGv3FBFpQTJN1RS1zvHC-ba4UG4ZLM0d7sviDn~w-2g4mn6SCL0Uq0re0GDfLmpQ23tcP-GZJMauRjQJtWHOjgtC7Dd2onSSRF425cnXp7I~kOa-wx0~iAZZU6B29KIKNAFKCgIe~5k3ml4Vn0Fd-Q-OZeYJCXPdfA2ZowXfrjUKsu-r6QFY0yLVySFswUpEEoFyvk3XBd2UXLc9YgQAE8tRvcrCNE5VHp30GQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour montage of the high-resolution images of all the SWELLS targets. The image sizes vary from 10 arcsec to 1 arcmin on a side, and each lens\u2019 grade is shown in parentheses next to its name. The three systems with grey-scale images only have AO K-band imaging. North is up, east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612881/mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612881\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=LsZMEIuTpe4oXbkJFAPi4afgyKjCfdpkgkM9T7LyrM9dEpHq3OvyUIrw5~JpuO7k7-RN6~6sfOJ3BO7PgWBJEERgbjtLfQr98zmMEwI3GD~EF02JT1uU5kD0dbS3tBuChOZV9jv2vzJSFkmDUzKbHzaJFwHGX2v~Pn-o007ttsmqBbzmOJotWgIUExhf6QvGPwt6E09eU9sMdR5z2B0~wKQAIu4LIHkgFP9LiZjJh7sksx-p0kzsqMkB3YP4GwkdAD8gqdhDei5ZHCAiMi00MepA6PcI4aLS96XVns7v-gHATtdkfvUqKe3sOnzWzu0j5DncNnnLboSsg-YalpZkMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612881&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour montage of the high-resolution images of all the SWELLS targets. North is up, east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=YquOg9UMTJqeA23PBABDf~8Kp~rZVob1Ie0abPWs3Xb~gLetHpgpKqA6BcNRi5N8rxIVqZxyRtqb1gw~9dcvxDI5R86gzS3Xud6fmwK5HuX55EmeqGv3FBFpQTJN1RS1zvHC-ba4UG4ZLM0d7sviDn~w-2g4mn6SCL0Uq0re0GDfLmpQ23tcP-GZJMauRjQJtWHOjgtC7Dd2onSSRF425cnXp7I~kOa-wx0~iAZZU6B29KIKNAFKCgIe~5k3ml4Vn0Fd-Q-OZeYJCXPdfA2ZowXfrjUKsu-r6QFY0yLVySFswUpEEoFyvk3XBd2UXLc9YgQAE8tRvcrCNE5VHp30GQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour montage of the high-resolution images of all the SWELLS targets. North is up, east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612881/mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612881\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=LsZMEIuTpe4oXbkJFAPi4afgyKjCfdpkgkM9T7LyrM9dEpHq3OvyUIrw5~JpuO7k7-RN6~6sfOJ3BO7PgWBJEERgbjtLfQr98zmMEwI3GD~EF02JT1uU5kD0dbS3tBuChOZV9jv2vzJSFkmDUzKbHzaJFwHGX2v~Pn-o007ttsmqBbzmOJotWgIUExhf6QvGPwt6E09eU9sMdR5z2B0~wKQAIu4LIHkgFP9LiZjJh7sksx-p0kzsqMkB3YP4GwkdAD8gqdhDei5ZHCAiMi00MepA6PcI4aLS96XVns7v-gHATtdkfvUqKe3sOnzWzu0j5DncNnnLboSsg-YalpZkMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612881&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour montage of the high-resolution images of all the SWELLS targets. North is up, east is left.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"19612882\" scrollto-destination=\"19612882\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=pNCa6Q3N2jkLuW3bMlD4v0KXuGcuiPUVfEOwzEXvph1TvX~d0QttrC3tTapvaHynE87tNBAkdxzCh7X9ekqNsYwTsL37coHS37Fw-o0RWD39Wu~QNs7k543juT6DStavHEQcFnc-HNQxghV8t-6yCtk3rt53mFVwMtvhvx~kF0NUllQJldbSvEWQLKWN0QSn7cmFHCint96sy7wOkdZON5Mtgxqsh1CnrYl1DCZyl98teuBU-oIZA8YEOgmgFldCz5tOkMmt1q31-eOSwVbcoiyqom~tUPS9hPXgvxrjOO8CcFLRDBJBW3SDre-LM0OhTmUCKICl82M3W3gLrREoYw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-band high-resolution images of the SWELLS targets. The top images are 10 arcsec on a side, while the residual images are 5 arcsec on a side to show the details of the potential sources identified in the SDSS spectroscopy. North is up, east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612882/mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612882\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=CaO4h6eI5tw7lcLWDgsUUqT4Ct~A~NFPwLJ~eq4ZKPo5QQMjBtH0GYF6ZbfbMOmY3Xz5n4oBbYK46X3K3lSFOmZYabALiD-ODY5C3Uingzj0iDRBf1dk60D1Cdsbhe6uqAQ-ici-mdneoYEC-4cH4AzrxYV~u69plJH1esV-8iDm-APuy1XGP6Dp6Z2J4fQ7AgwXtEJEMe8XrioswoPKel7K8~usykrLyMoRRYvG1AsE44NrWUYJkgiHrFrJZr58TjdTRcfEHlb~dubN-noBAgC5U3q2y6iublbLSeZzCOOVgqDIoGZjvMBGg74Ubweej8jlWcFD2ukVppvurh5k5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612882&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-band high-resolution images of the SWELLS targets. The top images are 10 arcsec on a side, while the residual images are 5 arcsec on a side to show the details of the potential sources identified in the SDSS spectroscopy. North is up, east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=pNCa6Q3N2jkLuW3bMlD4v0KXuGcuiPUVfEOwzEXvph1TvX~d0QttrC3tTapvaHynE87tNBAkdxzCh7X9ekqNsYwTsL37coHS37Fw-o0RWD39Wu~QNs7k543juT6DStavHEQcFnc-HNQxghV8t-6yCtk3rt53mFVwMtvhvx~kF0NUllQJldbSvEWQLKWN0QSn7cmFHCint96sy7wOkdZON5Mtgxqsh1CnrYl1DCZyl98teuBU-oIZA8YEOgmgFldCz5tOkMmt1q31-eOSwVbcoiyqom~tUPS9hPXgvxrjOO8CcFLRDBJBW3SDre-LM0OhTmUCKICl82M3W3gLrREoYw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Single-band high-resolution images of the SWELLS targets. For each system the top row shows the original image, and the bottom row shows the residual image after B-spline subtraction of the deflector. Missing bands are replaced by a cross. The top images are 10 arcsec on a side, while the residual images are 5 arcsec on a side to show the details of the potential sources identified in the SDSS spectroscopy. North is up, east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612882/mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612882\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=CaO4h6eI5tw7lcLWDgsUUqT4Ct~A~NFPwLJ~eq4ZKPo5QQMjBtH0GYF6ZbfbMOmY3Xz5n4oBbYK46X3K3lSFOmZYabALiD-ODY5C3Uingzj0iDRBf1dk60D1Cdsbhe6uqAQ-ici-mdneoYEC-4cH4AzrxYV~u69plJH1esV-8iDm-APuy1XGP6Dp6Z2J4fQ7AgwXtEJEMe8XrioswoPKel7K8~usykrLyMoRRYvG1AsE44NrWUYJkgiHrFrJZr58TjdTRcfEHlb~dubN-noBAgC5U3q2y6iublbLSeZzCOOVgqDIoGZjvMBGg74Ubweej8jlWcFD2ukVppvurh5k5A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612882&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-band high-resolution images of the SWELLS targets. For each system the top row shows the original image, and the bottom row shows the residual image after B-spline subtraction of the deflector. Missing bands are replaced by a cross. The top images are 10 arcsec on a side, while the residual images are 5 arcsec on a side to show the details of the potential sources identified in the SDSS spectroscopy. North is up, east is left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 4.2</a> we describe the morphological and structural properties of each deflector galaxy, based on visual inspection and of multicomponent, multiband surface photometry. Thirdly, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 4.3</a> we derive stellar mass for the bulge and disc component of each of the deflectors. We conclude in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 4.4</a> by investigating the dependency of the lens confirmation rate on the properties of the deflector and the lensing geometry.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612884 id=\"19612884\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 Lensing classification</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A summary of the SWELLS sample is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. All lenses were given a classification based on the scheme and criteria defined by the SLACS Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>). By consensus of a subset of the authors (TT, AAD, MWA, PJM, BJB), lenses were classified as secure (A grade), probable (B grade), possible (C grade) and not a lens (X grade). We note that our classification scheme is quite strict, and requires the convincing identification of multiple images. It is likely that most of the B grade lenses and some of the C grade systems could turn into A grade systems if deeper, or higher resolution, data were available to identify multiple images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the known late-type high-elongation lenses from the SLACS Survey (pre-cycle 16s), eight A grade previously unknown strong gravitational lenses were discovered as part of this project. Of the remaining 11 systems, there is one B grade and six C grade systems. Four systems were classified as definitely not lenses. Full gravitational lens models for the secure systems will be presented in future papers in this series (Paper II; Brewer et al., in preparation).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=19612888 id=\"19612888\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1-1>4.1.1 Notes on individual systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0820+4847 grade A</em>. Three-component arc to north-east of bulge. Deflector has almost edge-on disc. Bulge is small, suggesting a later type spiral, although spiral arms are not visible due to inclination. Observed with LGSAO, source appears as two lensed images, possibly indicating that the source has a red bulge and an extended blue disc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0821+1025 grade C</em>. Observed only with LGSAO. Foreground galaxy is high-inclination disc. Background galaxy is compact, 1.7 arcsec to the west. The background galaxy might be strongly lensed at fainter surface brightness levels. Blue band imaging might reveal multiple images. There is also another source, possibly a satellite of the main spiral galaxy, \u223c3 arcsec south-west of centre.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0841+3824 grade A</em>. The deflector is a grand design spiral with blue arms and a redder bar/disc. A simple lens model, reproducing the curved lensed feature, \u223c1.5 arcsec north-west of centre and the counter image on the opposite side, is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0915+4211 grade A</em>. Observed only with LGSAO. Clearly visible arc and counter arc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0955+0101 grade A</em>. The deflector is an edge-on discy galaxy. A blue and highly sheared arc is visible to the south-west of the bulge and the counter-image is clearly visible in the residuals, especially the <em>B</em> band. A simple lens model is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>. Another source, possibly a satellite of the deflector, or of the background source, is visible \u223c5 arcsec to the south of the deflector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1015+1750 grade X</em>. The deflector is a dusty star-forming edge-on spiral. The likely background galaxy is 1.6 arcsec to south-east. No <em>F814W</em> image. No evidence for highly sheared images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1029+0420 grade A</em>. The deflector is smooth and discy and seen edge-on, likely an early-type spiral or lenticular galaxy for the relatively large bulge. Arc and counter arc are clearly visible in the colour image and in the B-spline subtracted image. A simple lens model is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1032+5322 grade A</em>. The deflector is smooth and discy and seen edge-on. The lensed source is blue and has a complex morphology, likely a spiral with a redder bulge. Images and counter-images are clearly visible. A simple lens model is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1037+3517 grade A</em>. The main deflector is a spiral galaxy. However, a second peak in red surface brightness indicates either a merger in process or a multigalaxy lens, if the two galaxies are not in the same plane. Arc and counter arc are blue and clearly visible, although the morphology of the lensed images is not straightforward to interpret, owing to the complex lens potential. Could be a multigalaxy lens, possible second (compact red) lens galaxy at 1.10 arcsec to north. Extended source galaxy 2.4 arcsec to north. Integral field spectroscopy or high-resolution narrow-band imaging would help decipher this configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1056+0005 grade X</em>. Deflector galaxy is a bulge-less star-forming spiral. Likely background galaxy is seen 1.3 arcsec north of centre. No evidence of shear suggests that the source is well outside the caustics of the deflector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1103+5322 grade A</em>. The deflector is smooth and discy and seen edge-on. The lensed source is blue and has a complex morphology, likely a spiral with a redder bulge. Images and counter-images are clearly visible. A simple lens model is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1117+4704 grade A</em>. The deflector is smooth and discy and seen close to edge-on. A bright and highly sheared source is visible 1.6 arcsec north-east of deflector centre, albeit with no clear evidence for a counter-image. A classic \u2018fold\u2019 quadruply imaged source is visible in the <em>B</em>- and <em>V</em>-band B-spline residuals, with radius approximately 0.75 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1135+3720 grade A</em>. Observed only with LGSAO. Arc and counter-image are clearly visible in the B-spline residuals.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1203+2535 grade A</em>. Deflector galaxy has a blue edge-on disc and a red bulge; the outer edge of the disc is warped. Arc made of three merging images is clearly visible south-east of bulge. Possible quad with faint counter-image near the centre or naked cusp configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1228+3743 grade B</em>. Deflector is a grand design spiral. Background source is also extended with a red bulge and blue spiral arms, one of which passes close to the lens bulge. A possible arc and counter arc with image separation \u223c2 arcsec is visible in the residuals, clearest in the <em>B</em> band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1251</em>\u2212<em>0208 grade A</em>. The deflector has a red bulge and blue spirals arms. The lensed source is blue and high surface brightness. Images and counter-images are clearly visible in the B-spline residuals. Simple lens models are given in the papers by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008)</a>. A lensing and dynamics analysis is presented in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnabe et al. (2011)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1258</em>\u2212<em>0259 grade X</em>. Foreground galaxy has edge-on disc and bar-like structure. A possible background galaxy is seen 1.6 arcsec south of the deflector, with bulge and spiral arms. The source does not appear to be sheared and no counter-image candidate could be identified.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1300+3704 grade X</em>. Foreground galaxy is a large bulge-less edge-on star-forming spiral. Possible background galaxies 3.5 arcsec to north-east and south-west of deflector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1313+0506 grade A</em>. The deflector is smooth and discy and seen edge-on. The lensed source is blue and high surface brightness. Images and counter-images are clearly visible in the residuals. A simple lens model is given in the paper by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1321</em>\u2212<em>0115 grade C</em>. Foreground galaxy has edge-on disc with prominent dust lane. Blue background galaxy is seen 1.9 arcsec to north of the deflector. The source is elongated tangentially to the direction of the deflector suggesting strong shear. No counter-image could be identified, although it could be obscured by the prominent dust lane. High-resolution infrared images would be useful to confirm or reject the lensing hypothesis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1331+3638 grade A</em>. Deflector galaxy has blue spiral arms and a red bulge. Arc made of three merging images is clearly visible north-east of bulge. Possible quad with faint counter-image near the centre or naked cusp configuration. The target was observed with LGSAO, but faint tip-tilt star yielded poor correction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1410+0205 grade C</em>. The deflector has a red bulge, a prominent disc and a ring-like blue structure surrounding the bulge. The blue structure is most likely due to star formation in the deflector although lensing cannot be ruled out with current data. Another possible source is seen north-west of lens centre, although direction of the elongation is not obviously consistent with strong lensing. It could be that the source is only partially multiply imaged with the bulk of it extending outside of the caustic. Integral field spectroscopy or narrow-band imaging would be useful to decipher this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1521+5805 grade C</em>. Foreground galaxy has nearly edge-on disc with prominent dust lane. The background galaxy, with bulge and spiral arms, is visible north-west of deflector. It is possible that parts of the background source are multiply imaged but the dust lane and the complex morphology prevent a conclusive answer. High-resolution infrared images and integral field spectroscopy or narrow-band imaging would help.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1556+3446 grade C</em>. The deflector is a dusty nearly edge-on spiral galaxy. A possible image and counter-image is visible in the B-spline residuals. In the SDSS spectrum, background source has clear O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, H\u03b2, O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> emission lines. High-resolution <em>K</em>-band imaging would help see through the dust, while narrow-band imaging or integral field spectroscopy would help disentangle the light from the source and from the deflector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1703+2451 grade A</em>. The deflector is an edge-on dusty spiral, with boxy isophotes suggesting a pseudo-bulge. The outer disc is warped. A red(dened) arc and possible counter-image are clearly visible, especially in the LGSAO <em>K</em>-band B-spline residuals.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>2141</em>\u2212<em>0001 grade A</em>. Described in detail in Paper II, and more simply by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. (2008)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>2210</em>\u2212<em>0934 grade C</em>. The deflector has a prominent edge-on disc. Possible image and counter-images are visible in the B-spline residuals, with image separation \u223c1.3 arcsec. Another source, possibly a satellite of the main lens, is visible \u223c5 arcsec north of centre.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612925 id=\"19612925\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 Morphological and structural properties of the deflectors</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All the SWELLS deflectors show a clear discy component (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>), confirming our original selection based on SDSS images. Furthermore, the targets have high projected ellipticity, again consistent with our original selection based on SDSS images (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). Many of the targets show clear spiral arms, which in several cases are blue. Other targets are so close to edge-on that it is hard to identify spiral arms conclusively (notes on the morphology of individual targets are provided in the previous section). The overall morphology of the targets is also consistent with the distribution of velocity dispersions (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>); this distribution has a lower central value than the SLACS sample, which is dominated by massive elliptical galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"19612927\" scrollto-destination=\"19612927\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=Pr6499YvEizTawmARmYf0Gf3FuZgRlDmddzsa9yFmqCONAoONX5svjDJUpeZX5fgmAvSL3hlT051o3PHe3sKIseFEgs69Xu1mCKP~2oj5~1J9O85GWNWtFG-ZkyyZRIypCGXQ2epBRRWJ823i9O537~FXwTUIHOg6-osAWPTXe~44bgBuhRfRdCzjMh1lRhI5fQ458Q3D7HNgurGdPq6YbgAFggPZ6PgnKIUalXBZ12oJHTrjFyPi5FXlv1uwuHsz1loWfv3JKpk8yHB0oAnSVkolgRkFu0yBoiy82O4CLlITnbaOuai7APeNQoyk0TYT1Gl2XdeC~eeU5sDdMauow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of SDSS parameters for SWELLS lenses.
