Systems discovered prior to cycle 16s are plotted in red, our new systems are shown in black. Solid histograms represent secure lenses (A), hatched histograms represent probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open histograms represent non-lenses (X). Note that our cycle 16s strategy targeted preferentially lower velocity dispersion and axial ratio systems, in order to select disc edge-on galaxies. Note also how the confirmation rate increases with \u03c3, as expected.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612927/mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612927\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=Q-soPJlc5uQs3JqrUDVBetgYLF1mYp4hxXDPhThQzFY3ge0s4AH3fOeEgREX4KHCq~lLdBB4D2DHPbtK0lUMcK~9W6W7NN0eJj3OuOaY-2TSYyrMCDgGsbHZweC3HeVaZ1z-souLQrBvV7RGfpbP5c2giZTVmA-VQUm2b1KZfs~QU-AhhuMTsPvr0U0vRkj60qxxhczn4GNP3Kze8m6Mrw~bLwj3rbh2QCQbkql3UfCxGoN~Dnr2ws7l-3ZE8P7JIv-HaEFkuCYEiLvw65uoNUSgTkNqnC6RlpT7~xf~USmho5ff0E8Dw25532Ht8eqxHCHjhLnnFiM5EYQp~FyYZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612927&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of SDSS parameters for SWELLS lenses. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar velocity dispersions (when available, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), the middle panel shows the distribution of deflector redshifts and the bottom panel shows the distribution of axis ratios. Systems discovered prior to cycle 16s are plotted in red, our new systems are shown in black. Solid histograms represent secure lenses (A), hatched histograms represent probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open histograms represent non-lenses (X). Note that our cycle 16s strategy targeted preferentially lower velocity dispersion and axial ratio systems, in order to select disc edge-on galaxies. Note also how the confirmation rate increases with \u03c3, as expected.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=Pr6499YvEizTawmARmYf0Gf3FuZgRlDmddzsa9yFmqCONAoONX5svjDJUpeZX5fgmAvSL3hlT051o3PHe3sKIseFEgs69Xu1mCKP~2oj5~1J9O85GWNWtFG-ZkyyZRIypCGXQ2epBRRWJ823i9O537~FXwTUIHOg6-osAWPTXe~44bgBuhRfRdCzjMh1lRhI5fQ458Q3D7HNgurGdPq6YbgAFggPZ6PgnKIUalXBZ12oJHTrjFyPi5FXlv1uwuHsz1loWfv3JKpk8yHB0oAnSVkolgRkFu0yBoiy82O4CLlITnbaOuai7APeNQoyk0TYT1Gl2XdeC~eeU5sDdMauow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Histogram of SDSS parameters for SWELLS lenses. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar velocity dispersions (when available, see Table 1), the middle panel shows the distribution of deflector redshifts and the bottom panel shows the distribution of axis ratios. Systems discovered prior to cycle 16s are plotted in red, our new systems are shown in black. Solid histograms represent secure lenses (A), hatched histograms represent probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open histograms represent non-lenses (X). Note that our cycle 16s strategy targeted preferentially lower velocity dispersion and axial ratio systems, in order to select disc edge-on galaxies. Note also how the confirmation rate increases with \u03c3, as expected.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612927/mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612927\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=Q-soPJlc5uQs3JqrUDVBetgYLF1mYp4hxXDPhThQzFY3ge0s4AH3fOeEgREX4KHCq~lLdBB4D2DHPbtK0lUMcK~9W6W7NN0eJj3OuOaY-2TSYyrMCDgGsbHZweC3HeVaZ1z-souLQrBvV7RGfpbP5c2giZTVmA-VQUm2b1KZfs~QU-AhhuMTsPvr0U0vRkj60qxxhczn4GNP3Kze8m6Mrw~bLwj3rbh2QCQbkql3UfCxGoN~Dnr2ws7l-3ZE8P7JIv-HaEFkuCYEiLvw65uoNUSgTkNqnC6RlpT7~xf~USmho5ff0E8Dw25532Ht8eqxHCHjhLnnFiM5EYQp~FyYZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612927&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Histogram of SDSS parameters for SWELLS lenses. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar velocity dispersions (when available, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), the middle panel shows the distribution of deflector redshifts and the bottom panel shows the distribution of axis ratios. Systems discovered prior to cycle 16s are plotted in red, our new systems are shown in black. Solid histograms represent secure lenses (A), hatched histograms represent probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open histograms represent non-lenses (X). Note that our cycle 16s strategy targeted preferentially lower velocity dispersion and axial ratio systems, in order to select disc edge-on galaxies. Note also how the confirmation rate increases with \u03c3, as expected.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We quantify the structural properties of the deflectors by performing a bulge\u2013disc decomposition. For the purpose of this paper we adopt a simple parametrization, and describe the bulge with an elliptical <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">de Vaucouleurs (1948)</a> profile and the disc with an elliptical exponential profile. This parametrization is the same as that adopted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Simard et al. (2011)</a> to analyse the entire SDSS-Data Release 7 (DR7) data base, and therefore is ideal for a comparison between lenses and non-lens galaxies. Beyond this first analysis, in future papers we will derive more accurate descriptions of the surface brightness distribution by considering more flexible models, like e.g. the Sersic profile for the bulge (e.g. Paper II), and by correcting for extinction due to prominent dust lanes (Brewer et al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each deflector we compute the posterior probability distribution function of the parameters by comparing the models with the multicolour images using the dedicated code <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> developed by one of us (MWA; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bennert et al. 2011</a>). <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> replaces the functionality of standard codes like <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span>, by enabling a full exploration of the likelihood surface as well as joint analysis of multiband data. Furthermore, <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> models fit the multiband imaging simultaneously with the same effective radius, and the bulge effective radius is constrained to be smaller than the disc effective radius.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a> This procedure ensures self-consistent colours even with data of varying depth as a function of wavelength. The most probable values of the parameters are given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612930 id=\"19612930\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-3>4.3 Stellar mass</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Stellar mass estimates for the bulge and disc components of each candidate were derived by comparing multiband photometry with stellar population synthesis models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>). The method we employ provides not only stellar masses but also uncertainties that take into account all the relevant degeneracies between e.g. age and metallicity of the stellar populations. The dominant systematic uncertainty is the unknown normalization of the stellar initial mass function (IMF). Determining the absolute normalization of the IMF is one of the goals of the SWELLS survey (see Paper II). For the moment, we adopt two popular choices for the IMF, which are believed to bracket the appropriate range for spiral galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bell &amp; de Jong 2001</a>). Stellar masses for these <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Chabrier (2003)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Salpeter (1955)</a> IMFs are given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612932 id=\"19612932\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-4>4.4 Notes on the selection function</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The overall success rate for confirmation of SWELLS candidates in cycle 16s is 42 \u00b1 13 per cent (8/19) for A grade and 47 \u00b1 14 per cent (9/19) for A+B grade lenses. As expected, this is somewhat lower than the confirmation rate for massive early-type galaxies in the SLACS Survey, due to the fact that our galaxies are on average less massive: the Einstein radii are smaller and occupy a smaller fraction of the SDSS fibre. Furthermore, identifying multiple images is inherently more difficult behind spiral deflectors, due to the complexity of their surface brightness distribution and the presence of dust.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can investigate the selection function more quantitatively by studying the stellar mass structure of the deflectors and correlations of its properties with the confirmation rate. Mass and surface mass density are expected to be the key parameters determining the lensing strength of a galaxy. We will therefore investigate the dependency of confirmation rate on several proxies for mass and density.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a> we show the average stellar mass within circular apertures, expressed in units of the critical density <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-mu3.gif?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=1GBENaDfv-lJDfbowQav9tD8rP-zg1N5UjhV3Ms9Qs4AZZZ7hleyizUpUkqg3YrF6frW5BTXYM79AsDw2QGot5QIFSFeS6j4Da~mg7a0MXrbhZSDMa~25~QH7Q0gykv79r5lJ-IgkcfC26b5OaOzBUg-IkXZl4BLOWxOyXFvWx88u1KJ776BLGACsqjaezYqWTJc4TiSubzOVkkCzYVhnlKSfTsF1Sb5FC9ejqDh1MMsw1iXWTvzJAsq~yHJMgIsYKCz~OOShqBLcy1uV9q1Ka7rFBRV9fs073zxpuLYohjfGpOxm1bdMrMIefWBsoPwzSgfqMeNzI9LRVAqVmszbw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-mu3.gif\" />\u2060</span>, where <em>D</em><sub>s</sub><em>D</em><sub>d</sub> and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub> are the angular diameter distance to the source, to the deflector and between the deflector and the sources, respectively (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco 1992</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu 2010</a>). As shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a>, the enclosed average stellar mass density is always dominated by the bulge in the inner parts, although the disc starts to contribute significantly beyond 1 kpc. All of the secure systems have deflectors of uniformly high density, above critical density well beyond 1 kpc, even for a Chabrier IMF. The not-lenses span a broader range in surface mass densities including several systems that are significantly underdense compared to the grade A systems. Three out of four of the X grade lenses do not have a detectable bulge component (to our sensitivity limit of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> = 10<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>).</p>                        <a id=\"19612937\" scrollto-destination=\"19612937\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=vDgejgZ1ItNQ9TUcptv-aj~JEH3Xvb7a86x-rNrjo669~gYRbgiZO4CKcZjtso5vLeXp7UkvMbfs4wRP38CG7ZHqmx1ulMcnBOhMbebbBYTVtQfv6l6QdiPd4G62UqQ~CofKsYshZApwfr8qidiVMQCYlG5i2wJ~cJ-XOZT9~Zait1wrlSYbPjdHoMCOTRglvGoyZ88SqTRSHB7uHx-kDKXtZ0~f6op5yy8wmD67iL2GFA3stIKgbLw5bo1y3cLu1AOZwJ~-3UHt~5eC6kGF-car48spSQpFg6u1BLYdcfUkqao6ey68zgwxMfKfabNKQk~H8y9CQoDqOZTYMluN1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Average (enclosed) stellar surface mass density profile of SWELLS targets, in units of the critical density. The \u2018stellar Einstein radius\u2019 of each lens lies at the point where \u3008\u03a3\u3009/\u03a3crit\u2243 1. The black lines represent the total mass density profile, the red lines represent the contribution of the bulge and the blue lines represent that of the disc. Profiles for both the Salpeter and Chabrier IMF are shown. The top panel shows the profiles of secure (A) lenses, the middle panel shows the profile of probable (B) and possible (C) lenses and the bottom panel shows the non-lenses (X). Note that the bulge always dominates the enclosed average mass at small radii, while the discs start to provide a non-negligible contribution on scales of a kpc or larger.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612937/mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612937\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=PPLwbfjPONRSBmOYUd58Oa2wnLdNZApSHdpRyh3YhdfAvXhmHNfnvOjVoldWy4-Jlp0zMp3G2Y-aogbVCNg6J-I~SP0dIfUQvqt3Uq6mdOHxawKQBUvfZ-HakEEJNGUWdmeAquADe0z7hsQ9~PKyzHSyBOEEjRH1643TIIDHYPIbXyQ1eukC8X5i1S8zgRHmpB8VhbK6lR6rO8w~pTw9UVtgnW3BmVWQXpbJqIvFgaWmz8FhwD50fRuPIWCWRADxuxpe1TazEBWbYD1L5PwjEuw3fC9JZWOyfTD3FaixkqKzPjRCZU2PLKPLJUIyBrrjhHqqDIJN5y6nVyx59wtyKA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612937&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average (enclosed) stellar surface mass density profile of SWELLS targets, in units of the critical density. The \u2018stellar Einstein radius\u2019 of each lens lies at the point where \u3008\u03a3\u3009/\u03a3<sub>crit</sub>\u2243 1. The black lines represent the total mass density profile, the red lines represent the contribution of the bulge and the blue lines represent that of the disc. Profiles for both the Salpeter and Chabrier IMF are shown. The top panel shows the profiles of secure (A) lenses, the middle panel shows the profile of probable (B) and possible (C) lenses and the bottom panel shows the non-lenses (X). Note that the bulge always dominates the enclosed average mass at small radii, while the discs start to provide a non-negligible contribution on scales of a kpc or larger.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=vDgejgZ1ItNQ9TUcptv-aj~JEH3Xvb7a86x-rNrjo669~gYRbgiZO4CKcZjtso5vLeXp7UkvMbfs4wRP38CG7ZHqmx1ulMcnBOhMbebbBYTVtQfv6l6QdiPd4G62UqQ~CofKsYshZApwfr8qidiVMQCYlG5i2wJ~cJ-XOZT9~Zait1wrlSYbPjdHoMCOTRglvGoyZ88SqTRSHB7uHx-kDKXtZ0~f6op5yy8wmD67iL2GFA3stIKgbLw5bo1y3cLu1AOZwJ~-3UHt~5eC6kGF-car48spSQpFg6u1BLYdcfUkqao6ey68zgwxMfKfabNKQk~H8y9CQoDqOZTYMluN1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Average (enclosed) stellar surface mass density profile of SWELLS targets, in units of the critical density. The \u2018stellar Einstein radius\u2019 of each lens lies at the point where \u3008\u03a3\u3009/\u03a3crit\u2243 1. The black lines represent the total mass density profile, the red lines represent the contribution of the bulge and the blue lines represent that of the disc. Profiles for both the Salpeter and Chabrier IMF are shown. The top panel shows the profiles of secure (A) lenses, the middle panel shows the profile of probable (B) and possible (C) lenses and the bottom panel shows the non-lenses (X). Note that the bulge always dominates the enclosed average mass at small radii, while the discs start to provide a non-negligible contribution on scales of a kpc or larger.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612937/mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612937\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=PPLwbfjPONRSBmOYUd58Oa2wnLdNZApSHdpRyh3YhdfAvXhmHNfnvOjVoldWy4-Jlp0zMp3G2Y-aogbVCNg6J-I~SP0dIfUQvqt3Uq6mdOHxawKQBUvfZ-HakEEJNGUWdmeAquADe0z7hsQ9~PKyzHSyBOEEjRH1643TIIDHYPIbXyQ1eukC8X5i1S8zgRHmpB8VhbK6lR6rO8w~pTw9UVtgnW3BmVWQXpbJqIvFgaWmz8FhwD50fRuPIWCWRADxuxpe1TazEBWbYD1L5PwjEuw3fC9JZWOyfTD3FaixkqKzPjRCZU2PLKPLJUIyBrrjhHqqDIJN5y6nVyx59wtyKA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612937&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Average (enclosed) stellar surface mass density profile of SWELLS targets, in units of the critical density. The \u2018stellar Einstein radius\u2019 of each lens lies at the point where \u3008\u03a3\u3009/\u03a3<sub>crit</sub>\u2243 1. The black lines represent the total mass density profile, the red lines represent the contribution of the bulge and the blue lines represent that of the disc. Profiles for both the Salpeter and Chabrier IMF are shown. The top panel shows the profiles of secure (A) lenses, the middle panel shows the profile of probable (B) and possible (C) lenses and the bottom panel shows the non-lenses (X). Note that the bulge always dominates the enclosed average mass at small radii, while the discs start to provide a non-negligible contribution on scales of a kpc or larger.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In a circularly symmetric system the Einstein radius corresponds to the radius within which the average mass density equals the critical density (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schneider et al. 1992</a>). In order to obtain a proxy for the Einstein radius even when no lensing is detected we define the \u2018stellar Einstein radius\u2019 as the radius within which the average stellar mass density equals the critical density. Note that high-resolution multiband imaging is necessary to estimate this quantity robustly. Clearly this is only an approximation for non-circular systems, and will be a lower limit to the true Einstein radius if dark matter is present.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We are now in a position to study the distribution of integrated stellar mass <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, bulge-to-total stellar mass ratio <em>B</em>/<em>T</em> and stellar Einstein radii for the SWELLS targets. As shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a> all three quantities correlate at some level with confirmation rate. Most of the not-lenses are found at small <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, small <em>B</em>/<em>T</em> and small stellar Einstein radius. However, the correlation is not perfect: B and C grade lenses are found even at <em>M</em><sub>*</sub> &gt; 10<sup>11</sup> and <em>B</em>/<em>T</em> &gt; 0.7. All three objects with no detected bulge turned out to be not-lenses. Perhaps the cleanest predictor of confirmation is stellar Einstein radius: there are no confirmed lenses below 0.94 arcsec even though there are probable and possible lenses well above 1 arcsec. For comparison, the stellar Einstein radii for the confirmed SLACS early-type deflector galaxies are also typically (90 per cent) above 0.94 arcsec although 10 per cent of the values are in the range 0.69\u20130.94 arcsec. This tail of the distribution extending to smaller radii is consistent with the idea that multiple images with smaller separation can be detected in the presence of smooth early-type deflector galaxies compared to the case of spiral deflectors. However, the number of SWELLS targets is too small too reach a statistically significant conclusion.</p>                        <a id=\"19612940\" scrollto-destination=\"19612940\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=OfQjWfFhilowWa2F2nNdoI4cKcR6xKlB1KDWHSDQ04HFrG8ppRORNP30YmK4yf-m67ukLjM12ITwoLGZOs-jyeBzY-kRUG~TfspWG5JfaNirWNhhnGsVe8s57kbhm3wE5MBHoaamG84ejdk5yQ2hiu8b-JJlBKTtXGVbLMOiCj9uCAkid7VynbWJNataZ9YCJWg~5EzX9aYlzAC-Scj5xVWR1hM2ek6u~defzIA0G~pfsAlDRkPaoTnsdMbjjVaGOp3vEgM7WBWO91ayRQVn6WxGnIQq5cMGV9tjvTtDA4Jp97fOLo~S9j-7kd--7ul2tb0AYwV~xbbC6GBN4H8M-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of stellar mass related properties. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar Einstein radii, i.e. the radii within which the stellar surface mass density is equal to 1 in critical units, assuming a Chabrier IMF. This is an approximate lower limit to the actual Einstein radius, which will include the contribution of dark matter. The middle panel shows the distribution of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the distribution of bulge to total stellar mass ratio (the \u2018bulge fraction\u2019). As in Fig. 3, the red histogram represents lenses discovered prior to cycle 16s; the black solid, hatched and empty histograms represent lenses targeted in cycle 16, identified, respectively, as secure, probable and possible, and not-lenses. Note how no lens was confirmed with stellar Einstein radius below 0.94 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612940/mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612940\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=s8Ximf1nJ9i9HVkdrCMa6ppkCX5gNhmx3ArdmxT-flGH9xzlmV39zuqL8ii6IddOKcfSqONOOVlWD2wW6r61AfsXNz9jebKwtHlu8HTu1UVIwS8lQHuMoldCtMSr4bzLkSrnY3PBjyfMExeE7wG3i57GO2eleQVouWoKbHyX3iNnw8UjRLwCgLyToG2e8qY-RuDc461dLG5z0Rncg-RK3yKYyv9WT~2yzTcVp10qCB-TVm~jSp7CLFP0c33tdnWM9br-tGO5BFR09Pz7SpahNDERHft8JQ7OliFiMn4wGZ27NX8UHYg3QDGt8xEyRtIiknWD5NjsdQdGmO3uj4Emmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612940&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of stellar mass related properties. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar Einstein radii, i.e. the radii within which the stellar surface mass density is equal to 1 in critical units, assuming a Chabrier IMF. This is an approximate lower limit to the actual Einstein radius, which will include the contribution of dark matter. The middle panel shows the distribution of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the distribution of bulge to total stellar mass ratio (the \u2018bulge fraction\u2019). As in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>, the red histogram represents lenses discovered prior to cycle 16s; the black solid, hatched and empty histograms represent lenses targeted in cycle 16, identified, respectively, as secure, probable and possible, and not-lenses. Note how no lens was confirmed with stellar Einstein radius below 0.94 arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=OfQjWfFhilowWa2F2nNdoI4cKcR6xKlB1KDWHSDQ04HFrG8ppRORNP30YmK4yf-m67ukLjM12ITwoLGZOs-jyeBzY-kRUG~TfspWG5JfaNirWNhhnGsVe8s57kbhm3wE5MBHoaamG84ejdk5yQ2hiu8b-JJlBKTtXGVbLMOiCj9uCAkid7VynbWJNataZ9YCJWg~5EzX9aYlzAC-Scj5xVWR1hM2ek6u~defzIA0G~pfsAlDRkPaoTnsdMbjjVaGOp3vEgM7WBWO91ayRQVn6WxGnIQq5cMGV9tjvTtDA4Jp97fOLo~S9j-7kd--7ul2tb0AYwV~xbbC6GBN4H8M-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of stellar mass related properties. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar Einstein radii, i.e. the radii within which the stellar surface mass density is equal to 1 in critical units, assuming a Chabrier IMF. This is an approximate lower limit to the actual Einstein radius, which will include the contribution of dark matter. The middle panel shows the distribution of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the distribution of bulge to total stellar mass ratio (the \u2018bulge fraction\u2019). As in Fig. 3, the red histogram represents lenses discovered prior to cycle 16s; the black solid, hatched and empty histograms represent lenses targeted in cycle 16, identified, respectively, as secure, probable and possible, and not-lenses. Note how no lens was confirmed with stellar Einstein radius below 0.94 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612940/mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612940\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=s8Ximf1nJ9i9HVkdrCMa6ppkCX5gNhmx3ArdmxT-flGH9xzlmV39zuqL8ii6IddOKcfSqONOOVlWD2wW6r61AfsXNz9jebKwtHlu8HTu1UVIwS8lQHuMoldCtMSr4bzLkSrnY3PBjyfMExeE7wG3i57GO2eleQVouWoKbHyX3iNnw8UjRLwCgLyToG2e8qY-RuDc461dLG5z0Rncg-RK3yKYyv9WT~2yzTcVp10qCB-TVm~jSp7CLFP0c33tdnWM9br-tGO5BFR09Pz7SpahNDERHft8JQ7OliFiMn4wGZ27NX8UHYg3QDGt8xEyRtIiknWD5NjsdQdGmO3uj4Emmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612940&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of stellar mass related properties. The top panel shows the distribution of stellar Einstein radii, i.e. the radii within which the stellar surface mass density is equal to 1 in critical units, assuming a Chabrier IMF. This is an approximate lower limit to the actual Einstein radius, which will include the contribution of dark matter. The middle panel shows the distribution of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the distribution of bulge to total stellar mass ratio (the \u2018bulge fraction\u2019). As in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>, the red histogram represents lenses discovered prior to cycle 16s; the black solid, hatched and empty histograms represent lenses targeted in cycle 16, identified, respectively, as secure, probable and possible, and not-lenses. Note how no lens was confirmed with stellar Einstein radius below 0.94 arcsec.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In conclusion, the selection function of the new SWELLS targets is complex and comprised of multiple steps. In the first one, we pre-select based on SDSS images edge-on late-type galaxies. This is extremely efficient in producing a sample of lenticular and spiral galaxies. The second step, confirmation as a lens system, depends on the properties of the deflector but also has a stochastic component. Denser systems produce larger Einstein radii, which in turn make the lensing effect more likely and easier to detect at <em>HST</em> resolution. In addition, the relative position on the sky of the source and deflector, as well as the broad-band surface brightness of the source, ultimately control the presence of detectable multiple imaging. A third layer of complication is added by the presence of dust lanes and small-scale structure in the surface brightness distribution of the deflector, which may complicate identification of multiple images even for a perfectly good strong lensing system. In the next section we will investigate the effective selection function of the SWELLS sample by comparing the properties of the SWELLS deflectors with those of a typical sample of spiral galaxies.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612942 id=\"19612942\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 SWELLS GALAXIES AS SPIRAL GALAXIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Understanding the selection function of any observational sample is essential, both in order to generalize results to its parent population, as well as to compare across samples. In the case of the SWELLS sample the selection function of the deflectors is sufficiently complicated that it is extremely hard to compute it accurately from first principles. We therefore take an alternative approach and reconstruct the basic features of the selection function a posteriori by comparing the properties of the SLACS detectors to those of a suitable comparison sample of non-lens galaxies. The comparison sample should be as close as possible in terms of controllable galaxy parameters, so that significant differences might be interpreted unambiguously as due to the lensing selection effect. It is particularly useful to perform this comparison for both confirmed lenses and not-confirmed lenses as this will help separate the effects of our SDSS-based pre-selection from those related to the ability of the deflectors to produce detectable strong lensing events. In this paper we focus on the properties of the SWELLS deflector galaxies, and leave for future work the issue of whether they live in an overdense environment (which turns out not to be the case for the SLACS lenses; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Among the quantities that are well studied and available for large samples of galaxies, stellar mass and size (and therefore density) are particularly interesting and likely to influence the lensing selection function. We therefore choose to focus on the size\u2013stellar mass correlation as our comparison tool (for a similar analysis of the SLACS sample, based on the Fundamental Plane relation, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A suitable comparison sample for the SWELLS data set is its parent sample, the SDSS-DR7 data base itself. We adopt the results of the recent structural analysis performed by Simard et al. (in preparation). These authors fit two-dimensional models to the SDSS images, using the same parametrization for bulge and disc as was adopted in this study. The range in redshift and stellar mass of their sample is very similar to ours, and the parent sample is the same. To minimize differences with our sample, we construct the size\u2013mass relation for the SDSS sample limited to <em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6. Following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. (2011a)</a>, we construct the size\u2013mass relationship separately for the bulge, disc and total size, adopting the semimajor axis size for all three components. In contrast to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. (2011a)</a> we do not apply any selection based on stellar mass or spectral type. To minimize the impact of measurement biases we perform the comparison by also using sizes and stellar masses estimated using SDSS images for our sample of lenses.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a> The size\u2013mass relation for SDSS and for our deflector galaxies is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>. The top panel shows the relation between the total half-light radius and total stellar mass. The middle panel shows the relation between the half-light radius of the disc and the total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the relation between the half-light radius of the bulge and the total stellar mass. As a population, the deflector galaxies are consistent with being drawn from the SDSS parent population. We quantify this statement by comparing the vertical offset of each data point with the mean and standard deviation of the correlation, and computing a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> goodness of fit statistic.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a> We find \u03c7<sup>2</sup> = 26, 29 and 9, respectively, for total, disc and bulge, with 27 degrees of freedom for total and bulge and 26 for disc (one galaxy was omitted because of an unphysically small size returned by the SDSS catalogue, &lt;1 kpc). This shows that our selection of targets <em>at fixed stellar mass</em> is unbiased with respect to the parent SDSS population once the <em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6 cut is taken into account. Clearly, however, the distribution along the size\u2013mass relation is very different than that of the parent sample, since our target list was composed of almost exclusively of systems with mass above 10<sup>10.5</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> by design.</p>                        <a id=\"19612946\" scrollto-destination=\"19612946\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=EICm1FGGQ8bGcx0buq1Wgbfp0IK23ea6DDglz~x9iWNXCWP1AVxw9Rb9eQUl2HyP6J6w~6MYRGQ99Iqdq6l6eman56FQHBsWXtDWSprEbJmsWhAOc6SsYT9c7tjS5CtmuXooOB~wcTaO8bQHBAfWf~xsQL9Py4bJtXd3FJlVwNao2AcqjN8A6oGC2YxXLCWctDriKiR5Ybl0tVV6pBL6b3oZgDLMt-1Q7K-E2v0D7XQuYQZNAPoAJ1EueYCxbhV2LCB1caexEy47agd-SIPcLdN1c6af8P9fQhAKAj9JxLvIoEp2RxbaWziy174N5sb6-ZjTafi14zJTKna2HgMKuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The size\u2013mass relation for SWELLS deflector galaxies. The solid and dashed lines represent the mean, and 68 per cent intrinsic scatter, of the size distribution of SDSS galaxies at fixed mass with b/a &lt; 0.6. The points represent the SWELLS galaxies: solid squares are secure lenses (A), open stars are probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open squares are not lenses (X). Red symbols identify pre-cycle 16s targets, while black symbols identify cycle 16s targets. The top panel shows the total semimajor axis effective radius as a function of total stellar mass. The middle panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the disc component as a function of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the bulge component as a function of total stellar mass. We use the symbol R50 to identify the semimajor axis effective radius as measured from SDSS images, to distinguish it clearly from the circularized half-light radius measured from HST images and given in Table 2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612946/mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=CAIwcEPgdLBAv-V9XM4Mp73uDAebwN~exfrggnnjqto0nl6e50dAxREjqvREfVAj1vpF4tPACSqmzKKyXzmWLp11WD-~XvCZeYYSxa~XbG4Bt2TDEBryZIejjObxbasNFSz0TWfY4RKRzfvBFHRGwa3qeYltlMycfKMs4L5iYQzk35pKpuFE4pNe9SfaDcPetIfpDHIInRQtchLzQsFp3rK9RGyPIdhdXkBPnL1R6KOkjWYq5Ix1FanGM5UTZ04iZG7Bwt0qpnT1b~9QkyGVbaVsXx6rcA1nmsgAU75rmfxOjW90-XtZ~Nk9GAhZKrR4i9wutOH-J1EgCC7kRg4wQQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612946&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The size\u2013mass relation for SWELLS deflector galaxies. The solid and dashed lines represent the mean, and 68 per cent intrinsic scatter, of the size distribution of SDSS galaxies at fixed mass with <em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6. The points represent the SWELLS galaxies: solid squares are secure lenses (A), open stars are probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open squares are not lenses (X). Red symbols identify pre-cycle 16s targets, while black symbols identify cycle 16s targets. The top panel shows the total semimajor axis effective radius as a function of total stellar mass. The middle panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the disc component as a function of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the bulge component as a function of total stellar mass. We use the symbol <em>R</em><sub>50</sub> to identify the semimajor axis effective radius as measured from SDSS images, to distinguish it clearly from the circularized half-light radius measured from <em>HST</em> images and given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/m_mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&amp;Signature=EICm1FGGQ8bGcx0buq1Wgbfp0IK23ea6DDglz~x9iWNXCWP1AVxw9Rb9eQUl2HyP6J6w~6MYRGQ99Iqdq6l6eman56FQHBsWXtDWSprEbJmsWhAOc6SsYT9c7tjS5CtmuXooOB~wcTaO8bQHBAfWf~xsQL9Py4bJtXd3FJlVwNao2AcqjN8A6oGC2YxXLCWctDriKiR5Ybl0tVV6pBL6b3oZgDLMt-1Q7K-E2v0D7XQuYQZNAPoAJ1EueYCxbhV2LCB1caexEy47agd-SIPcLdN1c6af8P9fQhAKAj9JxLvIoEp2RxbaWziy174N5sb6-ZjTafi14zJTKna2HgMKuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The size\u2013mass relation for SWELLS deflector galaxies. The solid and dashed lines represent the mean, and 68 per cent intrinsic scatter, of the size distribution of SDSS galaxies at fixed mass with b/a &lt; 0.6. The points represent the SWELLS galaxies: solid squares are secure lenses (A), open stars are probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open squares are not lenses (X). Red symbols identify pre-cycle 16s targets, while black symbols identify cycle 16s targets. The top panel shows the total semimajor axis effective radius as a function of total stellar mass. The middle panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the disc component as a function of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the bulge component as a function of total stellar mass. We use the symbol R50 to identify the semimajor axis effective radius as measured from SDSS images, to distinguish it clearly from the circularized half-light radius measured from HST images and given in Table 2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/19612946/mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"19612946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/417/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.19378.x/2/mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467994&Signature=CAIwcEPgdLBAv-V9XM4Mp73uDAebwN~exfrggnnjqto0nl6e50dAxREjqvREfVAj1vpF4tPACSqmzKKyXzmWLp11WD-~XvCZeYYSxa~XbG4Bt2TDEBryZIejjObxbasNFSz0TWfY4RKRzfvBFHRGwa3qeYltlMycfKMs4L5iYQzk35pKpuFE4pNe9SfaDcPetIfpDHIInRQtchLzQsFp3rK9RGyPIdhdXkBPnL1R6KOkjWYq5Ix1FanGM5UTZ04iZG7Bwt0qpnT1b~9QkyGVbaVsXx6rcA1nmsgAU75rmfxOjW90-XtZ~Nk9GAhZKrR4i9wutOH-J1EgCC7kRg4wQQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=19612946&ar=1083532&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0417-1601-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The size\u2013mass relation for SWELLS deflector galaxies. The solid and dashed lines represent the mean, and 68 per cent intrinsic scatter, of the size distribution of SDSS galaxies at fixed mass with <em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6. The points represent the SWELLS galaxies: solid squares are secure lenses (A), open stars are probable and possible lenses (B and C), while open squares are not lenses (X). Red symbols identify pre-cycle 16s targets, while black symbols identify cycle 16s targets. The top panel shows the total semimajor axis effective radius as a function of total stellar mass. The middle panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the disc component as a function of total stellar mass. The bottom panel shows the semimajor axis effective radius of the bulge component as a function of total stellar mass. We use the symbol <em>R</em><sub>50</sub> to identify the semimajor axis effective radius as measured from SDSS images, to distinguish it clearly from the circularized half-light radius measured from <em>HST</em> images and given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is also interesting to consider whether the distribution of confirmed lenses is consistent with that of the parent population, or whether the confirmation rate appears to be a function of e.g. stellar mass density. By comparing the solid (grade A lenses) and open points (grades B, C and X) in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>, it appears that the solid points tend to lie preferentially somewhat below the open points. However, the difference is not significant. Even if we restrict to only the A grade lenses, they still appear to be consistent with the size\u2013mass relation of the SDSS parent population, at fixed stellar mass (\u03c7<sup>2</sup> = 18, 19 and 7 for 16 degrees of freedom, respectively, for total, disc and bulge component).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612948 id=\"19612948\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6 FINDING SPIRAL LENS GALAXIES: LESSONS LEARNT AND FUTURE PROSPECTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding spiral lens galaxies is more difficult than finding early-type lens galaxies for two reasons: (1) spiral galaxies tend to be less massive and less dense than early-type galaxies, and they therefore produce smaller image separations; (2) their complex surface brightness distribution and the presence of dust makes it hard to identify multiple images if they are present.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For these reasons a crucial element for the success of this search was the availability of multicolour high-resolution imaging data. However, for any given candidate it is not clear a priori which band will be most useful. In general, the SLACS sources are by selection star forming and therefore blue (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newton et al. 2011</a>), and stand out the most in the <em>F450W</em> filter. A good example of this phenomenon is J1117+4704, where the quadruply imaged source near the centre gradually disappears moving to longer wavelengths. In some cases, however, the presence of dust makes the infrared data crucial for studying the multiple images. An example of this phenomenon is J1703+2451, where the lensed source is barely visible in the optical images, while it is obvious in the infrared one. Interestingly, two of the lenses were confirmed purely on the basis of <em>K</em>\u2032 AO imaging. It appears that multiband photometry is an essential ingredient for future studies. At optical wavelengths <em>HST</em> is the only option for the time being. With current technology AO is only feasible for \u223c1/3 of high-latitude targets, and therefore a combination of AO (when possible) and <em>HST</em> (when AO is not possible) observations seems to be the most cost-effective strategy for the infrared.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The other crucial ingredient is angular resolution. This is useful especially for the detection of compact sources or central counter-images. Limited resolution is one of the reasons why we do not confirm any lens with stellar Einstein radius significantly smaller than 1 arcsec. A good example of this phenomenon is J0841+3824, where the counter-image is clearly visible in <em>I</em> band, but not at the lower resolution <em>H</em> band, even though this may in part be due to colour variations. The WFPC2 images obtained in cycle 16s significantly undersample the native <em>HST</em> PSF. Better sampled images with ACS or Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3)-Ultraviolet Imaging Spectrograph (UVIS) may result in an improved success rate. Higher resolution red/infrared images from Next Generation Advanced Optics or from the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> might combine the advantages of dust removal and angular resolution, even though colour contrast may still make blue/UV images competitive. Alternatively one may restrict the search to the systems with larger stellar Einstein radii to maximize success. However, high-resolution multiband images are needed to estimate this quantity accurately and therefore it does not appear a viable strategy for a large sample. Furthermore, one has to be mindful of the astrophysical implications of such a selection against objects where dark matter contributes significantly to the central mass density or where the IMF normalization is higher than normally assumed. Not to mention that finding lenses with small Einstein Radii is astrophysically interesting in its own right, in order to probe the structure of the lower mass galaxies and those with smaller bulges.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In terms of future prospects it seems that another way to improve the success rate would be to target emission lines in the sources at high resolution. This would be an efficient way to disentangle light from the source and deflector, and distinguish without any doubt multiple images from peculiar features in the surface brightness of the deflector. The rich filter complement of WFC3 aboard <em>HST</em> makes it the most promising instrument for this purpose. Targeting infrared lines might mitigate the effects of foreground extinction, although with the present targets only Paschen \u03b1 is accessible with decent Strehl and the line is typically too faint for present day integral field spectrographs, even on large 8\u201310 m telescopes. A tunable filter or custom-made filters will be necessary to pursue this goal. Alternatively, one could target lines in the radio mapping CO transitions or H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>. The Atacama Large Millimetre/submillimetre Array (ALMA) and Square Kilometer Array (SKA) will have the resolution and sensitivity to measure emission line maps of the source <em>and</em> lens, and will thus also offer the ability to measure kinematics of the lens and of the source. Molecular gas tends to trace the stars, so any source that is visibly lensed should also be lensed in CO. Neutral gas tends to be more extended (typically by a factor of 2 or more) than stars and molecular gas so this will increase the chances of strong lensing.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612954 id=\"19612954\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7>7 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The goal of the SWELLS survey is to study the distribution of luminous and dark matter in disc galaxies. With this goal in mind we have assembled an unprecedented sample of 27 candidate gravitational lens systems, where the deflector is a high-inclination disc galaxy. The sample is composed of eight systems previously discovered by the SLACS Survey for which we have obtained follow-up multiband high-resolution imaging, and 19 new targets. The new targets were selected from the SDSS data base to have multiple redshifts in the SDSS fibre, as well as elongated morphology. We present multicolour imaging of the sample, as well as structural parameters derived from this data for the whole sample. We then study the properties of the deflectors and compare them to a sample of non-lens galaxies selected from SDSS with the same criteria as our lens targets. Our main results can be summarized as follows.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the 19 new targets, eight are classified as A grade (secure) lenses, one is classified as B grade (probable), six are classified as C grade (possible) and four are classified as X grade (not lenses). Our global success rate in cycle 16s was 42 \u00b1 13 per cent for A grade lenses. The total number of A grade lenses in the SWELLS sample is 16.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">All the deflector galaxies have prominent discs observed at high inclination, by design. However, the sample spans a broad range of morphological and spectral types. It includes early-type spirals and lenticulars as well as later-type spirals, galaxies with strong H\u03b1 emission and galaxies with no detectable H\u03b1 emission. The stellar bulge to disc ratio of confirmed lenses range between 0.22 and 0.85, with an average of 0.55.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">All confirmed lenses have stellar masses above 10<sup>10.5</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and stellar Einstein radii above 0.94 arcsec. None of the low stellar mass density targets is confirmed to be a strong lens, consistent with the idea that stellar mass (as opposed to dark matter) dominates the mass density profile at the scales of a few kpc.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SWELLS targets and confirmed lenses follow the same size\u2013stellar mass relation as a comparison sample of high-elongation (<em>b</em>/<em>a</em> &lt; 0.6) non-lens galaxies selected from the SDSS survey. This implies that, <em>at given stellar mass</em>, SWELLS lenses are consistent with being representative of the overall population of high-elongation galaxies as identified by SDSS.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We conclude our study by summarizing some of the lessons learnt during this search. Key elements for a successful disc lens search appear to be high-resolution images spanning from the blue to the near-infrared, to exploit colour contrast as well as low dust extinction. The main remaining limitation is our ability to disentangle light from the deflector and source. Future studies should increase their success rate by targeting emission lines in the source at high resolution, via narrow-band imaging or integral field spectroscopy.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Three of these remaining targets were observed with <em>K</em>-band laser guide star adaptive optics (LGSAO) imaging on the Keck II telescope as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The priors for the surface brightness models are uniform but have meaningful bounds: \u00b15 pixels from the brightest central pixel for the centroid, 0.1 (0.15) to 1 for the axial ratio of the disc (bulge) and effective radii between 0.1 arcsec (2 pixels) and the size of the cut-out that is fitted by <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> (typically hundreds of pixels). Furthermore, the effective radii, flattening and position angle are the same for each filter, while the centroids of the bulge and disc are allowed a small shift of 3 pixels with respect to each other.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The SDSS sizes and masses are in remarkably good agreement to the <em>HST</em> determined ones, considering the difference in resolution. Nevertheless, the small differences are significant enough that they should be taken into account. Specifically, there is excellent agreement between the SDSS and <em>HST</em> determined stellar mass values, with no significant offset (0.04 \u00b1 0.03 dex), consistent with the findings of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. In contrast, the <em>HST</em>-determined sizes are on average 0.10 \u00b1 0.04 (disc) and 0.17 \u00b1 0.06 dex (bulge) smaller than those determined from SDSS images, with larger differences for the smaller objects. These differences are likely due to the higher spatial resolution of <em>HST</em> and/or a longer wavelength range used for our <em>HST</em> fits.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Errors on size can be neglected since they are much smaller than the intrinsic scatter of the correlation.</p></div></span></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank Matteo Barnab\u00e8 for useful discussions and suggestions. TT acknowledges support from the NSF through CAREER award NSF-0642621, and from the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship. AAD acknowledges financial support from a CITA National Fellowship, from the National Science Foundation Science and Technology Center CfAO, managed by UC Santa Cruz under cooperative agreement No. AST-9876783. AAD and DCK were partially supported by NSF grant AST 08-08133, and by <em>HST</em> grants AR-10664.01-A, <em>HST</em> AR-10965.02-A and <em>HST</em> GO-11206.02-A. PJM was given support by the TABASGO and Kavli Foundations, and the Royal Society, in the form of research fellowships. LVEK acknowledges the support by an NWO-VIDI programme subsidy (programme number 639.042.505). This research is supported by NASA through <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> programmes GO-10587, GO-11202 and GO-11978, and in part by the National Science Foundation under Grant No. PHY99-07949; and is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555, and at the W.M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. Funding for the SDSS and SDSS-II was provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, the US Department of Energy, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Japanese Monbukagakusho, the Max Planck Society and the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The SDSS was managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions. The SDSS Web Site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss.org/</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612967 id=\"19612967\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. A.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Burles</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">S.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2009</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">692</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1690</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/692/2/1690\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F692%2F2%2F1690\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F692%2F2%2F1690\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b47\" data-legacy-id=\"b47\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b47\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b47\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b47\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. W.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Koopmans</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. V. E.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Gavazzi</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Marshall</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. J.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bolton</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. S.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">709</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1195</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/709/2/1195\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F709%2F2%2F1195\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F709%2F2%2F1195\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b48\" data-legacy-id=\"b48\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b48\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b48\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b48\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Trott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C. M.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Koopmans</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. V. E.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Webster</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. L.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">401</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1540</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b49\" data-legacy-id=\"b49\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b49\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b49\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b49\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">van Albada</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. S.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Sancisi</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">1986</div>, <div class=\"source \">Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. Ser. A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">320</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">447</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b50\" data-legacy-id=\"b50\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b50\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b50\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b50\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">van den</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Bosch F. C.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Swaters</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. A.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2001</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">325</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1017</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1046/j.1365-8711.2001.04456.x\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1046%2Fj.1365-8711.2001.04456.x\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1046%2Fj.1365-8711.2001.04456.x\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b51\" data-legacy-id=\"b51\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b51\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b51\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b51\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Winn</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J. N.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hall</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. B.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Schechter</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. L.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2003</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">597</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">672</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/apj.2003.597.issue-2\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1086%2Fapj.2003.597.issue-2\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1086%2Fapj.2003.597.issue-2\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=19612968 id=\"19612968\" class=\"backappendixgroup-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendix</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=19612969 id=\"19612969\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11>APPENDIX A: SPECTROSCOPIC PRE-SELECTION OF SWELLS CANDIDATES</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The parent sample for the new SWELLS lens search consists of all SDSS-DR7 spectra with either good or marginal plate quality that are classified by the SDSS spectroscopic reduction pipeline as galaxies. Noise estimates for all spectra were rescaled on a plate-by-plate basis to be consistent with the statistics of sky-subtracted sky spectra on that plate.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectroscopic selection algorithm of the original SLACS sample and our new SWELLS sample both rely upon subtracting a model for the continuum of the foreground galaxy and scanning the residual spectrum for higher redshift emission features. For SLACS, these models were taken directly from the SDSS redshift pipeline, and consist of the best-fitting combination of four PCA-derived eigenspectra. For the absorption-dominated systems typical of SLACS, these models provide essentially noise-limited subtraction of the foreground galaxy continua. However, for emission-line foreground spectra, the quality of continuum subtraction with these models is much worse. Hence, we derived new continuum models by (1) generating a new PCA basis with seven eigenspectra, and (2) masking all common emission features in the foreground galaxy spectra before fitting each spectrum with this basis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The new models were subtracted from the target spectra, and the residual spectra were scanned automatically for either (1) multiple emission lines at a single background redshift, or (2) a single emission line consistent with a marginally resolved [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727 doublet. Potential [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] identifications were all checked for the presence of veto lines that would indicate H\u03b1, [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 5007 or H\u03b2 as a more likely identification. The set of spectra identified by the automated scan was visually inspected by one of us (ASB) and pruned of obvious false-positive detections related to night-sky subtraction residuals, broad emission-line wing residuals and spectra of generally bad data quality. Neighbouring fibres in the multifibre spectrograph image were also checked to make sure that candidate [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] detections were not due to cross-talk from bright emission lines in adjacent spectra, or to small-scale auroral emission in the night sky. The final list of potential target spectra was taken as the set which survived all visual inspections, and for which either (1) each of three distinct emission lines at the same background redshift was detected at 4\u03c3 or greater significance, or (2) a single candidate background [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission feature was detected at 7.5\u03c3 or greater significance. Candidate [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] systems were furthermore ranked as \u2018A\u2019 or \u2018B\u2019 based upon the appearance of doublet line structure, which can be marginally resolved at SDSS resolution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In total, out of almost a million spectra in the SDSS archive, our search algorithm found more than 200 new high-probability lens candidates, in addition to those already targeted by previous SLACS programmes (a similar number). The targets for the SWELLS programme were selected from this new pool of candidates as described in the main text.</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2011 The Authors. Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society \u00a9 2011 RAS</div><!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n        <span id=\"UserHasAccess\" data-userHasAccess=\"True\"></span>\r\n\r\n    </div><!-- class=\"articleListNewAndPopularCombinedView\">\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode active\" href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostCited\">Most Cited</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n    </ul>\r\n        <section class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert\">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nMagnetic field and chromospheric activity evolution of HD 75332: a rapid magnetic cycle in an F star without a hot Jupiter    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the lens grade (A \u2013 secure, B \u2013 probable, C \u2013 possible, X \u2013 not a lens) according to the definition of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span>Bolton et al. (2006); column 7 the velocity dispersion within the spectroscopic fibre as measured by SDSS; column 8 the H\u03b1 flux as measured by SDSS spectroscopy based on the subtracted model spectrum; column 9 the axial ratio as measured by SDSS and column 10 the reference for the discovery of the lens (1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span>Bolton et al. 2006, 2 \u2013<span class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the lens grade (A \u2013 secure, B \u2013 probable, C \u2013 possible, X \u2013 not a lens) according to the definition of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span>Bolton et al. (2006); column 7 the velocity dispersion within the spectroscopic fibre as measured by SDSS; column 8 the H\u03b1 flux as measured by SDSS spectroscopy based on the subtracted model spectrum; column 9 the axial ratio as measured by SDSS and column 10 the reference for the discovery of the lens (1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span>Bolton et al. 2006, 2 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span>Bolton et al. 2008, 3 \u2013 this paper).</p></div> </div><div For each lens the first line lists the bulge parameters (when detected), while the second line lists the disc parameters. Typical uncertainties are 0.05 mag on magnitudes, 10 per cent on effective radii and axial ratios (<em>q</em>=<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>), dominated by systematics (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span>Auger et al. 2009, and references therein). class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometric, structural and stellar mass parameters of the SWELLS systems. For each lens the first line lists the bulge parameters (when detected), while the second line lists the disc parameters. Typical uncertainties are 0.05 mag on magnitudes, 10 per cent on effective radii and axial ratios (<em>q</em>=<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>), dominated by systematics (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span>Auger et al. 2009, and references therein). Apparent magnitudes are not corrected for galactic extinction. (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\"
